channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Orders Halt to Construction of Government Buildings
item.description: The directive is the latest in a series of initiatives by President Xi Jinping to discourage corruption and grandiosity among widely mocked officials.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: 3 U.S. Soldiers Among 8 Killed in Afghan Bombing
item.description: An insurgent riding a donkey detonated a bomb in one of the most hotly contested districts in the country, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: The Lede: First Video of the Prince of Cambridge
item.description: Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge emerged from the hospital late on Tuesday and presented their infant to the crowds who had gathered outside the building for days.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:description: Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge appeared with their baby boy outside the Lindo Wing of St Mary's Hospital in London on Tuesday.

item.title: The Lede: Video of Navalny’s Return to Moscow
item.description: As he reported on his own blog over the weekend, the Russian opposition activist Aleksei A. Navalny was greeted by hundreds of supporters at a train station in Moscow on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot from the Russian activist Aleksei Navalny's blog showed supporters greeting him at a train station in Moscow on Saturday.

item.title: 2 Men Found Guilty Under Cameroon's Anti-Gay Law
item.description: A court in Cameroon found two men guilty under the country's harsh law banning gay sex on Tuesday, a lawyer said, continuing a string of recent convictions that has drawn international condemnation.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Royal Couple Make First Appearance with Infant Son
item.description: The Duchess of Cambridge and Prince William took turns cradling the newest royal heir in their arms to the screaming delight of onlookers.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: Prince William, Duke of Cambridge and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, with their newborn son at St Mary's Hospital on Tuesday in London.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 23
item.description: An artist in Amritsar, Punjab, finishing a portrait of Britain’s Prince William and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, along with their newborn.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: An artist in Amritsar, Punjab, giving final touches to a portrait of Prince William, right, with his wife, the former Kate Middleton, and their newborn. The British royal couple welcomed the newest member of their family, a baby boy, on Monday.

item.title: A Very British Proclamation
item.description: Celebrations for the new prince featured elements both traditional and modern, but all with a distinctly British touch.

item.title: Al Qaeda Asserts Responsibility for Iraqi Prison Breaks
item.description: The audacity of the assaults on Sunday, in which hundreds of inmates escaped, underscored the deterioration of Iraq’s stability in recent months.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Lens Blog: Photographing the Part of Buddhism That Can’t Be Seen
item.description: Beyond rituals and robes, David Butow set out to photograph the essence of spiritual experience among Buddhist monks in several countries.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: North Korea Is Said to Halt Upgrades at Rocket Launching Site
item.description: Satellite images show that work has stopped on a new launching pad and missile assembly building, a research institute reported.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: At War Blog: Tales of ‘White Taliban’ Sketch a New Legend
item.description: In Kandahar Province, one of the most volatile regions in Afghanistan, locals talk about a different breed of American Special Operations forces who settled in around 2005. They are said to drive civilian vehicles, wear local clothes, speak good Pashto – and yes, sport thick beards.
item.dc:creator: By HABIB ZAHORI

item.title: The Lede: Witness Accounts of New Violence in Egypt
item.description: Clashes between opponents and supporters of deposed Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi erupted in Cairo and a province just north of the capital on Monday, killing three people and injuring dozens more.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: Australians Question U.S. Reassurance After Navy Jettisons Bombs on Great Barrier Reef
item.description: Four bombs meant to be dropped on an island in an exercise had to be released at sea, the United States said, after unauthorized vessels entered the area.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: 6 Die in Egypt as Morsi Supporters Continue Protests
item.description: In the latest sign of Egypt’s political impasse, at least six people were killed Tuesday, bringing to at least nine the number of deaths in clashes over the last 24 hours.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Opponents of ousted President Mohamed Morsi helped an injured friend during clashes in Cairo late Monday.

item.title: India Ink: Supreme Court Restricts Tobacco Advertising
item.description: The Supreme Court on Monday overturned the Bombay High Court’s suspension of a law dealing with tobacco advertising in shops.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Cigarette packets displayed at a shop in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Nov. 27, 2007.

item.title: At Least 6 Killed in Cairo Clashes
item.description: State media reported violence between supporters and opponents of the deposed President Mohamed Morsi.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: The Female Factor: After Filibuster, a Star Rises in Texas
item.description: Since speaking out in the Texas Senate against a bill restricting abortion, the Democratic Senator Wendy Davis has been beseeched by supporters and some in her party to run for governor in 2014.
item.dc:creator: By LUISITA LOPEZ TORREGROSA

item.title: Prices Fuel Outrage in Brazil, Home of the $30 Cheese Pizza
item.description: From bus fare to rent, the price of living in Brazil keeps rising, and the push-back against increases has escalated from shopping abroad for cheaper goods to staging protests.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Biden Meets India’s Leaders to Promote Closer Ties
item.description: While in Mumbai, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to express growing concerns about India’s economy and its openness to foreign investment.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: U.S. Vice President Joe Biden and Sushma Swaraj, a leader of India's main opposition Bharatiya Janata Party, met in New Delhi, on Tuesday.

item.title: India Ink: Thomas Bernhard in New Delhi
item.description: The foundation stone of the 1984 Sikh massacre memorial was laid in Delhi in June. A novelist who survived the pogrom looks back.
item.dc:creator: By JASPREET SINGH

item.title: Biden Arrives in India in Effort to Improve Relations
item.description: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s visit, part of an effort to portray the Obama administration’s good will, is the first by a vice president in nearly 30 years.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Report Links Failed Afghan Project to Soldiers’ Deaths
item.description: Investigators say the failure to complete a program to keep insurgents from planting bombs in roadside drainage culverts may have resulted in the deaths of American soldiers.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: At War Blog: An Alternative for Afghan Peace Talks
item.description: Decentralizing power would allow the Taliban to get more of what they want in the areas where they have influence, while limiting them in areas where they have no influence, writes David H. Young, a former civilian adviser to NATO forces.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID H. YOUNG

item.title: Duchess of Cambridge Gives Birth to a Boy
item.description: Kensington Palace announced that the baby, who is now third in line to the throne, was delivered at 4:24 p.m. local time on Monday, weighing 8 pounds, 6 ounces.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: Crowds gathered to view the official notice of the birth of a son to Britain's Prince William and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge.
